questions.question: In which clinical test is the "Ring test" precipitation reaction applied, and what is its primary use?

options.A: Ascoliâ€™s thermo precipitin test for detecting anthrax antigens
options.B: VDRL test for detecting syphilis
options.C: Lancefield technique for grouping mycobacteria
options.D: Kahn test for detecting lupus antibodies

questions.explanation: This reaction is based on a precipitation reaction in a liquid medium. In this test, the suspected antigen is layered over an antiserum in a narrow tube, and a precipitate forms at the interface if anthrax antigens are present. Precipitation Reactions Soluble antigen and antibody combine to form antigen-antibody complex in the presence of electrolytes (e.g., NaCl) at the right temperature and pH to form an insoluble precipitate. Mechanism of precipitation Lattice hypothesis by Marrack: Precipitation results when a large lattice forms from alternating antigen and antibody molecules in the zone of equivalence In the Zones of antigen or antibody excess, the lattice does not enlarge, as the valencies of the antibody and the antigen, respectively, are fully satisfied. Prozone phenomenon occurs when there is too much antigen in relation to the amount of antibody in the test. Postzone phenomenon occurs when there is too much antigen in relation to the amount of antibody in the test. Types: Precipitation reaction in liquid Precipitation reaction in the gel Precipitation reaction in liquid Ring test Flocculation tests Ring test: Antigen layered over antiserum in a narrow tube; precipitate forms at the interface Application: Ascoli's thermo precipitin test - diagnosis of anthrax (Option A) Grouping of streptococci by the Lancefield technique (Option C ruled out) Flocculation tests Slide test: Antigen and the antiserum (antibody) are placed on a slide and mixed by shaking; floccules appear Application: VDRL test for syphilis (Option B ruled out) Tube test: Tube is used instead of a slide Application: Kahn test for syphilis (Option D ruled out)

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections and a history of autoimmune disease. Laboratory tests reveal a deficiency in complement component C3. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this deficiency?

options.A: Increased susceptibility to infections by Neisseria meningitidis
options.B: Impaired opsonization and phagocytosis, leading to severe bacterial infections
options.C: Development of hereditary angioneurotic oedema
options.D: Enhanced immune complex clearance and reduced inflammation

questions.explanation: bacterial infections, particularly from pyogenic bacteria. Complement Deficiency: Definition : Complement deficiencies arise from genetic defects in complement components or regulatory proteins, compromising both innate and acquired immunity. Clinical Manifestations : Vary from mild recurrent infections to severe life-threatening conditions. Consequences of Complement Deficiency: Impaired Immune Clearance : Reduced ability to clear microbial antigens and immune complexes leads to: Recurrent Infections : Increased susceptibility to bacterial and fungal infections, especially with C3 deficiencies. Common infections include pneumonia, skin infections, and sepsis due to pyogenic bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus , Streptococcus pneumoniae ). Neisserial Infections : Terminal complement deficiencies (C5-C9) increase susceptibility to Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae , leading to meningitis, septicaemia, and gonorrhoea. (Option A ruled out) Autoimmune Diseases : It is associated with conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) due to impaired clearance of immune complexes, resulting in tissue deposition, inflammation, and damage. Specific Deficiencies and Associated Syndromes: Deficiency Condition/Clinical Manifestation C1 Inhibitor Deficiency (Option C ruled out) Hereditary angioneurotic oedema: Uncontrolled activation of classical pathway causes episodic swelling (can be life-threatening). C3 Deficiency Increased susceptibility to severe recurrent pyogenic infections; impaired opsonization, phagocytosis, and immune complex clearance. C5-C9 Deficiencies Increased susceptibility to bacteraemia, especially with Gram-negative diplococci; impaired formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Enhanced immune complex clearance and reduced inflammation (option D) are incorrect, as C3 deficiency leads to impaired clearance and increased inflammation due to the accumulation of immune complexes. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 128

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes the pathways of complement activation? antibodies. residues on pathogens. formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC).

options.A: The classical pathway is triggered by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 and does not require
options.B: The alternative pathway is initiated by the binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose
options.C: The lectin pathway involves the binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes, leading to the
options.D: All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

questions.explanation: C3 into C3a and C3b. regardless of the pathway triggered. This is a key feature of the complement system, allowing for a unified response to pathogen invasion. Complement System: Definition : A complex network of at least 30 proteins in the blood, crucial for innate and acquired immunity. Functions : Lysis : Directly kills pathogens by forming membrane pores. Opsonization : Coats pathogens to enhance recognition and uptake by phagocytes. Immune Clearance : Removes immune complexes from circulation. Inflammation : Triggers release of mediators, recruiting immune cells. Pathways of Complement Activation: Pathway Trigger Mechanism Key Components Involved Classical Pathway Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes (Option A ruled out) C1q, C3 convertase, Membrane Attack Complex (MAC) Alternative Pathway Direct binding of complement proteins to pathogens (Option B ruled out) C3, factors B and D, C3 convertase Lectin Pathway Binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose (Option C ruled out) MBL, MASP1, MASP2, C4, C2, C3 convertase Key Points: Convergence : All pathways converge at the formation of the C3 convertase. C3 Convertase : Cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b, leading to the formation of C5 convertase and, ultimately, MAC. Regulation : The complement system is tightly regulated to prevent excessive activation and damage to host tissues. Regulatory Proteins : Include inhibitors and inactivators that control the cascade.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics of Immunochromatographic Card Tests is NOT accurate?

options.A: A) They provide rapid results, often within 15-30 minutes.
options.B: B) The tests for Hepatitis B can detect both antibodies and antigens.
options.C: C) They are primarily used in well-equipped laboratory settings only.
options.D: D) The sensitivity and specificity of these tests can be greater than 90%.

questions.explanation: Immunochromatographic Card Tests: Purpose : Rapid detection of infectious diseases including Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, COVID-19, and malaria. Advantages : Quick results (15-30 minutes) (Option A ruled out) High sensitivity and specificity Useful in resource-limited settings Disease-Specific Findings: Disease Type of Detection Sensitivity (%) (Option D ruled out) Specificity (%) (Option D ruled out) Note Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) Antibodies (anti-HBs) or antigens (HBsAg) (Option B ruled out) > 95 > 99 Reliable for initial screening Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) Antibodies against HCV 90 - 98 95 - 100 Critical for quick identification COVID-19 IgM and IgG antibodies 98.68 (IgM), 98.72 (IgG) 93.10 (IgM), 100 (IgG) Effective for serological diagnosis Rapid antigen tests 94.3 100 Effective for early diagnosis Malaria Specific antigens from malaria parasites 90 - 95 ~95 Timely treatment decisions are critical Reference: https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acssensors.0c00927 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33946860/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8457631/

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the indirect immunofluorescence test? application.

options.A: A) It requires specific fluorescent conjugates for each antigen being tested.
options.B: It uses an antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect any human antibody, allowing for broader
options.C: It directly labels antigens with a fluorescent dye for visualisation.
options.D: It is primarily used to detect antigens in brain smears, such as in rabies diagnosis.

questions.explanation: allowing for broader application. making it versatile and reducing the need for multiple conjugates. Immunofluorescence: Technique to visualise antigen-antibody interactions using fluorescent dyes. Developed by Coons et al. in 1942. Diagnostic and research applications for identifying antigens in tissues. Principle of Immunofluorescence: Fluorescence : A substance absorbs specific light wavelengths and emits light at a longer wavelength. Fluorescent Dyes : Appear bright when exposed to UV light, allowing visualisation of antibody-bound antigens under a microscope. Types of Immunofluorescence Tests: Type Description Example Limitation Direct Immunofluorescence Detects antigen directly using a fluorescent-labelled antibody. (Option C ruled out) Rabies diagnosis via brain smears (Option D ruled out) Requires separate fluorescent conjugates for each antigen. (Option A ruled out) Indirect Immunofluorescence It uses antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect human antibodies, enhancing versatility. Fluorescent treponemal antibody test for syphilis Allows the use of a single anti-human conjugate. Procedure for Indirect Immunofluorescence (e.g., Treponemal Antibody Test): Apply a drop of patient serum on a T. N pallidum smear. Incubate and wash to remove unbound components, leaving a bound antibody. Add fluorescent-labelled anti-human gamma globulin; binds to the patientâ€™s antibody on treponemes. Wash off unbound conjugates; examine under UV light. Positive test: Treponemes fluoresce against a dark background. Applications of Fluorescent Dyes in Immunology: Conjugation with Complement Proteins : Enables detection of antigens/antibodies. Sandwich Technique : Used to detect antibodies involving a labelled secondary antibody. Immunohistochemistry : Combines serology specificity with histology for tissue visualisation. Flow Cytometry : Fluorescence-based cell identification and counting with specific markers. Advantages and Disadvantages of Immunofluorescence: Advantages Disadvantages High sensitivity for detecting small amounts of antigen/antibody. Non-specific fluorescence due to autofluorescence or non-specific binding. High specificity with target-specific antibodies. Photobleaching (loss of fluorescence over time with light exposure). Versatile: applicable to various samples (tissues, cells, microorganisms). High cost of equipment and reagents. Allows direct visualisation, aiding interpretation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Chemiluminescent Immunoassays (CLIA) is TRUE?

options.A: A) CLIA exclusively uses fluorescent dyes to detect antibodies in clinical samples.
options.B: The sensitivity of the VITROSÂ® SARS-CoV-2 Ag Test is reported to be 94.3%.
options.C: CLIA methods have lower diagnostic accuracy compared to traditional serological tests.
options.D: Neutralising antibody levels against SARS-CoV-2 can only be detected using RT-PCR

questions.explanation: accurately reflects the performance metrics of this CLIA-based antigen detection kit. Chemiluminescent Immunoassays (CLIA): Definition : Advanced diagnostic tools using chemiluminescence to detect specific antibodies or antigens in clinical samples. Mechanism : Utilises a chemiluminescent reaction that emits light due to a chemical reaction. (Option A ruled out) Highly sensitive; capable of detecting low analyte concentrations in serum or plasma. (Option C ruled out) Applications in SARS-CoV-2 Detection: Application Details Performance Metrics Neutralising Antibodies Automated CLIA was developed for detecting neutralising antibody (NAb) levels against SARS-CoV-2. Sensitivity: 87.4% Specificity: 78.1% Antigen Detection VITROSÂ® SARS-CoV-2 Ag Test evaluated against RT-PCR and rapid antigen tests (RATs). Sensitivity: 94.3% Specificity: 100% Comparative Performance: Serological Assays : CLIA methods effectively detected SARS-CoV-2 antibodies over time. Some assays maintained high sensitivity, while others showed reduced performance after several months. Indicates the necessity for periodic reassessment of assay parameters. Diagnostic Accuracy: Clinical Settings : Different CLIA methodologies showed diagnostic accuracies. Sensitivities exceeding 85% for previous COVID-19 infections. High specificity across various tests, confirming CLIA's reliability in serological testing. Neutralising antibody levels against SARS-CoV-2 can only be detected using RT-PCR (Option D) , which is incorrect because specific automated CLIA assays are developed to detect neutralising antibodies, not just RT-PCR. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8660141/ https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34896578/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8457631/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10675702/ https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34986501/

questions.question: Which type of ELISA involves an antigen in the sample competing with a known antigen for a limited amount of antibody, resulting in an inverse colour change curve?

options.A: A) Sandwich ELISA
options.B: B) Indirect ELISA
options.C: C) Competitive ELISA
options.D: D) Capture ELISA

questions.explanation: antigen for binding to a limited amount of antibody. Higher antigen levels result in less colour change, creating an inverse curve. ELISA Types: ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) is a popular serological method known for its versatility, sensitivity, simplicity, and cost-effectiveness . It is commonly used in diagnostic labs due to commercial test kits and automation options. Types of ELISA: Type Description Application Example Homogeneous ELISA One-step procedure; no separation of bound and free fractions needed. Suitable for analysing haptens like drugs. Enzyme-multiplied immunoassay technique (EMIT) for drug detection Heterogeneous ELISA Multi-step process requiring separation of bound and free fractions (e.g., by centrifugation). Commonly used for microbial antigen and antibody detection. Standard ELISA ELISA Methods: Method Description Example Sandwich ELISA (Option A ruled out) Used to detect antigens by capturing them between two antibodies (capture and detection antibodies). Detection of rotavirus antigen in faeces Indirect ELISA (Option B ruled out) Used to detect antibodies in the sample. Anti-HIV antibody test Competitive ELISA Antigen in the sample competes with known antigen for a limited amount of antibody; produces an inverse curve (less colour at higher antigen levels). Hapten detection Capture ELISA (Option D ruled out) Highly specific for detecting specific antigens. Various immunometric tests Sandwich ELISA Procedure: Coating : Coat microtiter wells with goat anti-rotavirus antibody; add sample and incubate (overnight at 4Â°C or 2 hours at 37Â°C). Detection Antibody : Add enzyme-labelled anti-rotavirus antibody (e.g., with alkaline phosphatase) and incubate. Substrate Addition : Add para-nitrophenyl phosphate; enzyme activity causes colour change if rotavirus is present. Interpretation : Yellow colour development confirms a positive test; the ELISA reader provides quantitative colour readings. ELISA Modifications: Modification Description and Application Example Cylinder/Cassette ELISA For rapid, small-scale testing using disposable cassettes. Results are read visually without special equipment. Dot Blot Assay for HIV detection Sandwich ELISA Used specifically for antigen detection. Detection of food toxins and adulterants Key Applications of ELISA: Disease Diagnosis : HIV, hepatitis, and other infectious diseases. Food Safety : Detection of toxins and adulterants.

questions.question: In the Complement Fixation Test (CFT), what indicates a positive result?

options.A: Lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)
options.B: Formation of an immune complex between antigen and antibody
options.C: No lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)
options.D: Presence of active complement in the serum

questions.explanation: complement is fixed by the immune complex formed between antigen and antibody, leaving no free complement to lyse the SRBCs. Complement Fixation Test (CFT): Purpose : Detects specific antigens or antibodies in serum by measuring complement fixation. Principle : Immune complex (antigen-antibody binding) fixes complement, which is then detected using sensitised sheep red blood cells (SRBCs). Procedure of CFT: Step Description Step 1: Complement Fixation 1. Heat patient serum to inactivate native complement. 2. Add known antigen or antibody and complement. 3. Immune complex fixes the complement if a specific antigen or antibody is present. Step 2: Indicator Stage 1. Add sensitised SRBCs (coated with amboceptor) to the mixture. 2. Positive CFT: Complement fixed, no SRBC lysis. 3. Negative CFT: Free complement lyses SRBCs. Applications: Sensitivity : Detects 0.04 mg of antibody nitrogen and 0.1 mg of antigen. Example : Wassermann reaction for syphilis diagnosis. Limitations: Requires precise standardisation of reagents. Sera may contain non-specific complement inhibitors, leading to false positives. Indirect Complement Fixation Test: Modification : Used for sera that cannot fix guinea pig complement (e.g., avian/mammalian sera). Method : Add standard antiserum that can fix complement after the first CFT stage. Positive Result : Hemolysis occurs if antigen-antibody binding has consumed the complement. Other Complement-Dependent Serological Tests: Test Type Description Immune Adherence Bacteria aggregate and adhere to cells (e.g., erythrocytes) in the presence of complement and specific antibodies. Immobilisation Test Antibodies inhibit bacterial motility with complement (e.g., Treponema pallidum immobilisation test). Cytolytic/Cytocidal Tests Bacteria are lysed or killed when mixed with specific antibodies and complement. Lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs) (Option A) indicates a negative result, as it shows that the complement was not fixed, and the SRBCs are free to be lysed. Formation of an immune complex (Option B) occurs in both positive and negative results but does not directly indicate a positive outcome. Presence of active complement in the serum (Option C) before heating could interfere with the test, but it is not an indicator of a positive result. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 112, 113, 114

questions.question: A 30-year-old Rh-negative G2P1L1 woman is evaluated during her routine prenatal visit. What would be the significance of performing an indirect Coombs test at this stage?

options.A: To determine the motherâ€™s ABO blood type
options.B: To check for antibodies against Rh-positive blood
options.C: To confirm the sensitization of red cells with antibodies in the fetus
options.D: All of the above

questions.explanation: blood cells, which is important at this stage in assessing the risk of Rh incompatibility in the fetus. Coombs (Antiglobulin) Test Originally developed for the detection of anti-Rh antibodies that do not agglutinate Rh-positive erythrocytes in saline. Principle : Incomplete anti-Rh antibodies coat Rh-positive red cells without causing agglutination. When these coated cells are washed and treated with Coombs serum (anti-human globulin), agglutination occurs Types : Direct Coombs Test : Detects in vivo sensitization of red cells with antibodies, used in cases like hemolytic disease of the newborn due to Rh incompatibility (sample for test is blood from the baby) (Option C ruled out) Indirect Coombs Test : Detects in vitro sensitization by adding patient serum to test red cells, useful for blood transfusion compatibility and antibody screening (sample for test is blood from the mother) Applications : Initially, for anti-Rh antibody detection. It also detects other incomplete or non-agglutinating antibodies, such as in brucellosis. To determine the motherâ€™s ABO blood type (Option A): It is important to know the motherâ€™s ABO blood type for managing potential blood group incompatibilities. However, it is not the primary purpose of the indirect Coombs test at this stage, especially considering she is Rh-negative and having a second pregnancy. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: Which type of agglutination test is typically used for blood typing?

options.A: Heterophile Agglutination test
options.B: Co-agglutination test
options.C: Direct Agglutination test
options.D: Passive Agglutination test

questions.explanation: their surface in the presence of corresponding antibodies. When blood is mixed with anti-A or anti-B antibodies, direct agglutination occurs if the specific antigens are present in the red blood cells. Agglutination Reactions Clumping of particulate antigens with specific antibodies in the presence of electrolytes at the right temperature and pH More sensitive than precipitation for antibody detection Principle: Agglutination occurs optimally when antigens and antibodies react in equivalent proportions The zone phenomenon may be seen when either an antibody or an antigen is in excess Incomplete or monovalent antibodies do not cause agglutination, though they combine with the antigen Types Direct (Active) Agglutination : Antibody reacts directly with particulate antigen Slide Agglutination : Used for bacterial identification, blood grouping, and cross-matching (Option C) Tube Agglutination : Quantitative; used in diagnosing brucellosis, typhus, and for the Widal test Heterophile Agglutination Tests : (Option A ruled out) Weil-Felix Reaction : Diagnoses typhus fevers Streptococcus MG Test : Diagnoses primary atypical pneumonia Paul-Bunnell Test : For infectious mononucleosis Coombs (Antiglobulin) Test : Detects anti-Rh antibodies and antibodies in brucellosis Indirect (passive) Agglutination : Soluble antigens attached to carrier particles make agglutination tests more sensitive and convenient (Option D ruled out) Carrier Particles : Red blood cells, latex particles, or bentonite Hemagglutination : Detects rheumatoid arthritis (RA) factor Latex Agglutination : Detects anti-streptolysin O (ASO), C-reactive protein (CRP), RA factor, and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) Co-agglutination : Uses Staphylococcus aureus with Protein A to bind antibodies, causing visible clumping when reacting with specific antigens (Option B ruled out)

questions.question: The image below shows a precipitation test in a gel medium in which a circular precipitation pattern is formed due to an antigen-antibody reaction. What type of precipitation test in the gel does this image depict?

options.A: Ouchterlony Procedure
options.B: Radial immunodiffusion
options.C: Oakley-Fulthorpe Procedure
options.D: Counterimmunoelectrophoresis

questions.explanation: and diffuses outward through a gel containing evenly distributed antibodies. As the antigen diffuses radially, it forms a circular precipitation ring. The size of this ring is proportional to the antigen concentration. Precipitation Reactions in Gel Immunodiffusion in a soft agar or agarose gel forms visible, stable bands of precipitation that can be stained Advantages: Distinct, preservable precipitation bands allow easy observation of different antigens Types and Modifications: One-Dimension: Agar gel in a test tube Two-Dimension: Agar gel on a flat surface (slide or petri dish) Single Diffusion: Antigen diffuses towards antibody One-Dimension (Oudin Procedure) Two-Dimension (Radial Immunodiffusion): Antigen diffuses radially, forming ring-shaped bands (Option B) Application: Screening sera for antibodies (e.g., influenza viruses) Double Diffusion: Antigen and antibody move toward each other. One-Dimension (Oakley-Fulthorpe Procedure) (Option C ruled out) Two-Dimension (Ouchterlony Procedure) : (Option A ruled out) Compares different antigens and antisera directly. Application: Elek test for diphtheria toxigenicity. Immunoelectrophoresis: Involves the electrophoretic separation of a composite antigen (such as serum) into its constituent proteins, followed by immunodiffusion against its antiserum, resulting in separate precipitin lines, indicating a reaction between each individual protein with its antibody. Electroimmunodiffusion: Combines electrophoresis and immunodiffusion by electrically driving antigen and antibody diffusion. Counterimmunoelectrophoresis (CIE): (Option D ruled out) Electrophoresis of antigen and antibody in opposite directions; precipitation forms between them. Application: Detects antigens like alpha-fetoprotein and specific antigens of Cryptococcus and Meningococcus in cerebrospinal fluid. Ro cket Electrophoresis (One-Dimension Single Diffusion): Antigen, in increasing concentrations, is placed in wells punched in the set gel. The antigen is then electrophoresed into the antibody-containing agarose Application: Quantitative estimation of antigens

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes a pro-antigen ? carrier protein.

options.A: A molecule that binds to carrier proteins to become immunogenic and trigger an immune response.
options.B: A substance that directly triggers an immune response without any modification.
options.C: A molecule that requires metabolic conversion into reactive intermediates to become immunogenic.
options.D: A compound that can bind to antibodies but does not provoke a full immune response without a

questions.explanation: become immunogenic. to trigger immune responses. Haptens, Pro-Antigens, and Incomplete Antigens: Term Definition Mechanism Clinical Relevance Haptens LMW compounds (<1000 Da) that require binding to carrier proteins to trigger immune response Bind to proteins to form conjugates, recognized by T cells, stimulating humoral and cellular responses (Option A ruled out) Associated with allergic contact dermatitis (e.g., nickel, penicillin) Pro-Antigens Substances needing metabolic conversion to become immunogenic (Option B ruled out) Metabolized into reactive intermediates, then bind proteins, forming immune-triggering complexes Example: Urushiol in poison ivy, requiring activation to cause allergy Incomplete Antigens Molecules that bind to antibodies or T-cell receptors but donâ€™t provoke full immune response alone (Option D ruled out) Require attachment to larger carrier molecules to be immunogenic Involved in immune tolerance and sensitization mechanisms Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4052058/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK6573/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4264915/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3138048/

questions.question: Which immunoglobulin is most closely associated with the early stages of B cell response and is found alongside IgM on unstimulated B lymphocytes?

options.A: IgA
options.B: IgD
options.C: IgE
options.D: All of the above

questions.explanation: antigen and causes specific stimulation of the B cell - either activation or cloning to produce antibodies or suppression. IgA: (Option A ruled out) Two types â€“ IgA1 and IgA2 Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears Two Forms : Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA Secretory IgA: Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines) Role in Local Immunity : Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens. Resistance : Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents Activates the alternative complement pathway IgD: (Option B) IgD and IgM occur on the surface of unstimulated B lymphocytes Function: Acts as recognition receptors for antigens It causes specific stimulation of the B cell - either activation or cloning, to produce antibodies or suppression. IgE: (Option C ruled out) Heat-labile (sensitive to heat) It has an affinity for the surface of tissue cells (particularly mast cells) of the same species (homocytotropism) Mediates Prausnitz-KÃ¼stner Reaction Distribution : Primarily found in extravascular spaces Elevated Levels : In atopic conditions (type I allergies) like asthma, hay fever, eczema, and parasitic infections Function : Protects against pathogens by triggering mast cell degranulation and releasing inflammatory mediators Immunoglobulin Functions : IgG: Protects body fluids IgA: Protects body surfaces IgM: Guards the bloodstream IgE: Mediates allergic hypersensitivity IgD: Present on the surface of B lymphocytes Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 6th Edition, Page 99, 100, 101.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about IgG, but not IgM?

options.A: It requires a J chain for polymerisation.
options.B: It has a valency of 10.
options.C: It is the only antibody that can cross the placenta.
options.D: It is the first antibody produced by the fetus.

questions.explanation: newborns. IgG Four types â€“ IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, and IgG4 It is the main serum immunoglobulin , constituting 80% of total serum antibodies Distribution: Both intravascular and extravascular Only maternal antibody transported across the placenta , providing passive immunity to newborns (Option C) mop Function : Binds to microorganisms, enhancing their phagocytosis Participates in complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralisation of toxins/viruses Part of chronic inflammation Clinical Application : Used in isoimmunisation for Rh-negative mothers with anti-Rh(D) IgG during delivery. IgM It is a heavy molecule, hence called 'the millionaire molecule.â€™ Structure: Made of five four-peptide subunits; requires a J chain for polymerisation (Option A ruled out) Valency : 10 (Option B ruled out) Distribution: Primarily intravascular (80% of IgM) Early Production : First antibody synthesized by the fetus , starting around 20 weeks of gestation (Option D ruled out) Short-Lived : IgM antibodies degrade sooner than IgG Immune Hemolysis : One IgM molecule can induce hemolysis, unlike IgG, which requires 1,000 molecules for similar effect Opsonization Efficiency : 500-1,000 times more effective in opsonization than IgG Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 6th Edition, Page 98, 99, 100.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the enzymatic digestion of immunoglobulins is incorrect?

options.A: Papain digestion results in the formation of two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment.
options.B: Mercaptoethanol irreversibly cleaves disulfide bonds, separating heavy and light chains.
options.C: Pepsin digestion produces one F(ab')2 fragment and several smaller peptide fragments.
options.D: Pepsin digestion cleaves the Ig molecule above the disulfide bridge in the hinge region.

questions.explanation: region. formation of an F(ab')2 fragment and additional smaller fragments. Enzymatic Digestion of Immunoglobulins Papain Digestion Mechanism: Cleaves Ig above the disulfide bridge in the hinge region. Results: Generates three fragments: (Option A) Two Fab Fragments: Soluble fragments that bind to antigens (Ag). One Fc Fragment: Insoluble, crystallizes when cold. Pepsin Digestion Mechanism: Cleaves the Ig molecule below the disulfide bridge in the hinge region. Results: Produces: (Option C) One F(ab')2 Fragment: Two Fab subunits are still bound together. Many Smaller Fragments: Additional peptide fragments result from further cleavage. Mercaptoethanol (Option B) Function: Irreversibly cleaves disulfide bonds. Outcome: Separates all heavy chains and light chains of the immunoglobulin. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 95, 96

questions.question: A 25-year-old man is preparing for a trip to Africa and South America. The healthcare provider informs him that he needs a yellow fever vaccine, which is important for preventing the disease. Which of the following statements about the yellow fever vaccine is incorrect?

options.A: The vaccine is effective in providing long-lasting immunity
options.B: Immunity from the vaccine develops immediately after vaccination.
options.C: The vaccine contains a live attenuated virus
options.D: It is a form of artificially acquired active immunity.

questions.explanation: vaccination. Active immunity The most common type of immunity developed in response to infection or vaccination. Characteristics: Resistance developed as a result of antigenic stimulation. Used for prophylaxis to enhance body resistance. Types: Natural Active Immunity Artificial Active Immunity Naturally acquired active Immunity Development: Forms after exposure to antigens via natural processes (e.g., infection). The body's immune system produces antibodies in response. Duration: It can be long-lasting (e.g., smallpox, measles, chickenpox, yellow fever). May diminish over time (e.g., diphtheria, tetanus, influenza). Premunition: A special type of immunity observed in syphilis, is also called infection immunity. Rapidly acquired, short-lived, and partially effective. Immunity lasts only as long as the original infection is active. Artificially acquired active immunity Definition: Induced by vaccination. Process: Carefully chosen antigens (e.g., vaccines, toxoids) are intentionally introduced. The immune system synthesizes antibodies in response. Immunity duration: Typically provides long-term immunity. Vaccines available: Against diseases such as cholera, tuberculosis, plague, pneumonia, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, smallpox, polio, tetanus, influenza, measles, rabies, and yellow fever. Toxoids: Available for protection against diphtheria and tetanus, where major effects are due to toxins. Options(A, C, and D) are accurate. The vaccine provides long-lasting immunity, contains a live attenuated virus, and represents a form of artificially acquired active immunity. Learning Objective: Category Active Immunity Passive immunity Source Produced by the individual's own immune system. Acquired from an external source Mechanism The immune system responds to the antigen by producing its own antibodies Pre-formed antibodies are transferred into the individual. Onset of Immunity It takes time to develop Immediate protection after administration. Duration of Immunity Long-lasting Short term Quality Has high quality and is more effective This is transient and less effective Memory Formation The immune system retains the memory of the pathogen. No memory is formed; immunity is not long-term. On subsequent dose Shows booster effect Is less effective In Immunodeficient It may be ineffective or insufficient in patients with severe immunodeficiencies Critical for immunodeficient individuals Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 84, 85

questions.question: A 68-year-old man presents with complaints of persistent fatigue, bone pain, and frequent infections. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated serum protein levels. A peripheral blood smear shows rouleaux formation. Which of the following statements regarding the types of antibodies produced is correct?

options.A: The antibodies recognize different epitopes and show variability.

questions.question: A 19-year-old college student presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of fatigue, sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. On examination, he has significant posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The physician suspects a viral infection and decides to perform a specific agglutination test. Which of the following statements regarding this test is correct?

options.A: The test detects heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep red blood cells.
options.B: An agglutination titer of 50 or below is indicative of a positive result.
options.C: The test requires fresh serum samples without any prior heating.
options.D: Heterophile antibodies are produced only in response to one type of virus

questions.explanation: principle behind the Paul-Bunnell test, which is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The test identifies heterophile antibodies present in the patient's serum that can agglutinate sheep red blood cells, which is a characteristic immune response associated with this viral infection. Heterophile Antigens Definition: A type of hetero-antigen present in different species that share epitopes. Cross-Reactivity: Antibodies produced against an antigen from one species can react with the heterophile antigen from another species and vice versa (Option D) Diagnostic Applications: Heterophile antigens are used in various serological tests to detect antibodies in patient serum. Examples of Tests: Weil-Felix Reaction: Used to diagnose certain infections, such as rickettsial infections. Paul-Bunnell Test: Primarily used for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis. Cold Agglutination Test: This test is used to detect specific antibodies that cause agglutination at low temperatures. This test is primarily used to identify mycoplasma pneumonia. Streptococcus MG Test: Used to detect antibodies associated with streptococcal infections. Paul-Bunnell Test Purpose: Diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Method: Utilizes sheep red blood cells (RBCs) as antigens to detect heterophile antibodies in the patientâ€™s serum. Principle: In infectious mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes. These antibodies can also occur after serum injections and in some normal individuals. Procedure: The inactivated serum is prepared by heating at 56Â°C for 30 minutes (Option C) The serum is mixed in doubling dilutions with an equal volume of a 1% sheep erythrocyte suspension. Incubate at 37Â°C for 4 hours. Interpretation: Examine for agglutination. An agglutination titer of 100 or above suggests infectious mononucleosis (Option B) Note: The Paul-Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes ; the Monospot test, horse red cells. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 482

questions.question: Which of the following factors is most likely to decrease the immunogenicity of a substance?

options.A: Large molecular size of the antigen
options.B: Metabolic resistance to degradation by enzymes
options.C: Parenteral route of administration
options.D: Presence of adjuvants

questions.explanation: enzymatic degradation, like polystyrene latex, cannot be processed effectively, reducing their immunogenicity. Factors Affecting Immunogenicity: Factor Description Details Molecular Size Larger molecules are more immunogenic. (Option A ruled out) High MW molecules (e.g., hemocyanins) are strongly antigenic. Small molecules (<5000 MW) are weak or non-antigenic. Chemical Nature Composition affects immunogenicity. Proteins and polysaccharides are highly antigenic. Lipids and nucleic acids are weak antigens, but binding to proteins enhances their antigenicity. Foreignness Non-self substances are immunogenic. "Self" substances are non-immunogenic. The degree of foreignness matters; antigens from the same species are less immunogenic than those from other species. Susceptibility to Enzymes Immunogenic substances must be metabolically degradable. Antigens require a breakdown by phagocytes for immune cell recognition. Substances resistant to degradation (e.g., polystyrene latex) are non-antigenic. Route of Administration Route influences the immune response. Parenteral administration (e.g., injection) elicits a stronger response than oral/nasal. (Option C ruled out) Injection site matters (e.g., hepatitis B vaccine is more effective in the deltoid than the gluteal muscle). Antigen Dose Dose impacts immune response strength. An optimal dose is required for a strong response. High doses can cause immunological paralysis. Repeated exposure enhances response. Adjuvants Enhance immunogenicity through various mechanisms. (Option D ruled out) Depot adjuvants (e.g., aluminium hydroxide) increase antigen persistence. Immunostimulatory adjuvants (e.g., Freund's complete) activate immune cells. Genetic Factors Genes influence immune response to specific antigens. Immune response (Ir) genes control individual immune responses to particular antigens. Age and Nutritional Status Age and nutrition affect immune system maturity. Immune development is gradual; infants and young children are less responsive. Malnutrition suppresses immune responses. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 90, 91, 151, 152
